Question_1.Context: The study aimed to select the optimal microbial agents for reducing ammonia gas in Chinese cabbage cultivation.
Question_1.Question: What were the ammonia emission reduction efficiencies of the nitrification microorganisms, Alcaligenes faecalis subsp. faecalis and Brevibacillus sp.?
Question_1.Source: The ammonia emission reduction efficiencies of the nitrification microorganisms, Alcaligenes faecalis subsp. faecalis and Brevibacillus sp. were 21 and 31%, respectively, which were superior to those of other microorganisms.

Question_2.Context: The study evaluated the optimum mixing ratio of microbial agents for removing ammonia gas emitted from NPK-containing soil.
Question_2.Question: What was the optimum mixing ratio of microbial agent for removing ammonia gas emitted from NPK-containing soil?
Question_2.Source: The optimum mixing ratio of microbial agent for removing ammonia gas emitted from NPK-containing soil was: acid‑producing microorganism:Alcaligenes faecalis subsp. faecalis:Brevibaillus sp. = 0.70:0.15:0.15.

Question_3.Context: The study assessed the reduction efficiency of ammonia emissions from NPK-containing soil under optimum conditions in cabbage cultivation.
Question_3.Question: How much lower was the reduction efficiency of ammonia emissions from NPK-containing soil under optimum conditions compared to the control?
Question_3.Source: The reduction efficiency of ammonia emissions from NPK-containing soil under optimum conditions in cabbage cultivation was 27% lower than that of the control (only NPK-containing soil).

Question_4.Context: The study investigated the effects of nitrifying microorganisms on ammonia emission characteristics in soil containing NPK.
Question_4.Question: What was the trend of ammonia emissions from the NPK-containing soil treated with nitrifying microorganisms compared to the control?
Question_4.Source: Ammonia gas discharged from the NPK-containing soil with nitrifying microorganisms increased rapidly on the 2nd day after treatment and thereafter decreased gradually.

Question_5.Context: The study examined the effects of acid-producing mixed microorganisms on ammonia emission characteristics.
Question_5.Question: How much lower was the cumulative ammonia emission in the NPK-containing soil treated with acid-producing microorganisms compared to the control?
Question_5.Source: The cumulative ammonia emission for 20 days in the NPK-containing soil treated with acid-producing microorganisms was 2.5 kg/ha, which was 55% lower than that in the soil containing only NPK.

Question_6.Context: The study investigated the reduction efficiency of ammonia emissions from NPK-containing soil according to the mixing ratio of nitrifying and acid-producing mixed microorganisms.
Question_6.Question: Which mixing ratio showed the highest reduction efficiency of ammonia emissions compared to NPK-containing soil?
Question_6.Source: Cumulative ammonia emissions from NPK-containing soils according to the mixing ratio of the two nitrifying and acid-producing microorganisms were in the order of SMM1 (2.7 g/ha) > SMM3 (2.4 g/ha) > SMM2 (2.0 g/ha), and the ammonia reduction efficiency compared to NPK-containing soil was in the order of SMM2 (65%) > SMM3 (57%) > SMM1 (51%). Therefore, SMM2 was the optimum microbial mixing condition for reducing ammonia gas in NPK-treated soil.

Question_7.Context: The study evaluated the ammonia reduction efficiency during cabbage cultivation according to the application of microbial agents.
Question_7.Question: What was the cumulative ammonia emission from the cabbage culture according to the optimal microbial agent treatment amount?
Question_7.Source: When 500, 1000, and 2000 L/ha of microbial agents were applied to NPK-containing soils, the cumulative amounts of ammonia released were 25.9, 27.7, and 33.7 kg/ha, respectively, which were lower than those of NPK-containing soils not treated with microorganisms.

Question_8.Context: The study analyzed the growth characteristics of Chinese cabbage under different microbial agent application levels.
Question_8.Question: What was the yield of Chinese cabbage treated with NPK and the microbial agent once compared to untreated cabbage?
Question_8.Source: The yield of Chinese cabbage treated with NPK was more than three times higher than that of untreated cabbage, and when 500 L/ha of the microbial agent was applied to the NPK-containing soil, the yield was 94.2 Mg/ha.

Question_9.Context: The study examined the distribution of microbial communities in the soil with and without microbial agent treatment during cabbage cultivation.
Question_9.Question: What was the distribution ratio of Proteobacteria immediately after the microbial agent and NPK were applied to the soil?
Question_9.Source: The distribution ratio of Proteobacteria immediately after the microbial agent and NPK were applied to the soil was 53.9%; however, it decreased to 35.3% after 30 days of treatment.

Question_10.Context: The study analyzed the variations of microbial communities in Chinese cabbage cultivation soil with chemical fertilizer and microbial agent.
Question_10.Question: What was the trend of Firmicutes distribution ratio 30 days after treatment with microbial agent and fertilizer?
Question_10.Source: The distribution ratios of Firmicutes were 0.3%, 2.9%, and 1.4% immediately after treatment with fertilizer and microbial agent, and 30 and 65 days after treatment, respectively, and were the highest 30 days after treatment with microbial agent and fertilizer.
